data.title: Anguillidae - freshwater eels
meta_keywords: Anguillidae - freshwater eels | Wildlife Journal Junior
data.meta_description: There are 15 species in this family. Unlike other eels, members of this family have scales. they have a long doral fin that runs from the middle of their back to their tail. They have a anal fin that runs from the middle of their stomach to the tip of their tail. They have small, rounded pectoral fins just behind their gills. Freshwater eels are catadromous, that means they live in freshwater and migrate downstream to spawn in the ocean. Young eels live in the ocean or in estuaries until they are around one year old. Year old eels are called elvers. Elvers return to rivers to grow to adulthood. The American eel is the only native freshwater eel found in North America. American eels are found in rivers in the eastern United States. American eels migrate to the Sargasso Sea near Bermuda to spawn. The adults probably die after spawning. The elvers return to inland rivers when they are a year old. Females many travel well inland, males usually stay near river mouths or in estuaries. American eels can be as much as 15 years old when they spawn. Female American eels can grow to be four feet long, males are around 1.5 feet long.  - Wildlife Journal Junior
data.text:
Most freshwater eels are catadromous, that means they live in freshwater and migrate downstream to spawn in the ocean. Young eels live in the ocean or in estuaries until they are around a year old. One-year-old eels are called elvers. Elvers return to rivers to grow to adulthood.

The American eel is the only native freshwater eel found in North America. American eels are found in rivers in the eastern United States. Every winter mature American eels migrate to the Sargasso Sea near Bermuda to spawn. The adults probably die after spawning. Most American eel elvers return to inland rivers when they are a year old. Females may travel well inland; males usually stay near river mouths or in estuaries. Just recently scientists discovered that not all American eel elvers return to freshwater to mature. Some stay in marine or estuarine habitats. American eels are now described as displaying facultative catadromy. That means they can be found in freshwater or saltwater during maturation.

American eels can be as much as 15 years old when they spawn. Female American eels can grow to be 4 feet long; males are around 1.5 feet long.

Resource Key

Profile Photos Video Audio

American Eel - Anguilla rostrata

The American eel spawns in the Atlantic Ocean and moves into streams and rivers in North and South America.

Source: Arkive Intended Audience: General Reading Level: Middle School

American Eel - Anguilla rostrata

The American eel is found from Greenland to Brazil.

Source: US Fish and Wildlife Intended Audience: General Reading Level: Middle School

American Eel - Anguilla rostrata

The American eel larvae spends up to a year in the ocean, drifting in the ocean currents.

Source: North American Native Fishes Association Intended Audience: General Reading Level: Middle School

European Eel - Anguilla anguilla

The European eel is found on the floor of the ocean or river in which it is living.

Source: Animal Diversity Web Intended Audience: General Reading Level: Middle School

Indonesian Shortfin Eel - Anguilla bicolor

Indonesian shortfin eels live in fresh water areas as an adult and in estuaries and seas as young

Source: Fish Base Intended Audience: General Reading Level: High School

Japanese Eel - Anguilla japonica

Japanese eels may crawl over land at night from one place to another.

Source: Fish Base Intended Audience: General Reading Level: High School

Marbled Eel - Anguilla marmorata

Marbled eels have well developed and fleshy lips.

Source: USGS Non indigenous Aquatic Species Database Intended Audience: General Reading Level: Middle School

Pacific Shortfin Eel - Anguilla obscura

The Pacific shortfin eel is found from western New Guinea and Queensland, Australia to the Society Islands.

Source: Fish Base Intended Audience: General Reading Level: High School

Polynesian Longfin Eel - Anguilla megastoma

The Polynesian longfin eel is found in rocky pools, often in coastal streams.

Source: Fish Base Intended Audience: General Reading Level: High School

Short-finned Eel - Anguilla australis

Short-finned eels are found in streams, lakes, and swamps.

Source: Fish Base Intended Audience: General Reading Level: High School

Indian Mottled Eel - Anguilla bengalensis

The Indian mottled eel is found in Pakistan, India, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Burma, Bangladesh, and the East Indies.

Source: Fish Base Intended Audience: General Reading Level: High School

Mottled Eel - Anguilla nebulosa

The mottled eel is found from East Africa to Indonesia.

Source: Fish Base Intended Audience: General Reading Level: High School

Indonesian Longfin Eel - Anguilla borneensis

Indonesian longfin eels are found in Indonesia, Malaysia, and the Philippines.

Source: Fish Base Intended Audience: General Reading Level: High School

Celebes Longfin Eel - Anguilla celebesensis

Celebes longfin eels are found in Indonesia, Malaysia, and the Philippines.

Source: Fish Base Intended Audience: General Reading Level: High School

Highlands Long-finned Eel - Anguilla interioris

Highland longfin eels are found in Indonesia and Papua New Guinea.

Source: Fish Base Intended Audience: General Reading Level: High School

African Longfin Eel - Anguilla mossambica

African longfin eels are found in rivers on the east coast of Africa and on Madagascar. They can be found well inland.

Source: Fish Base Intended Audience: General Reading Level: High School

Philippine Mottled Eel - Anguilla luzonensis

Philippine mottled eels are found in the Philippines.

Source: Fish Base Intended Audience: General Reading Level: High School
